summary: The South-East Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) was established in 1954 as a collective defense arrangement aimed at preventing the spread of communism in Southeast Asia. Although it is categorized under world organisations, SEATO's relevance extends to EU legal and regulatory frameworks, particularly in matters of international relations and security cooperation. The EU often engages with multilateral organizations to enhance regional stability and promote democratic governance. As a redirect to the preferred term "SEATO," this concept underscores the importance of international treaties and alliances in shaping EU foreign policy and regulatory approaches to global security challenges.
